title: Bulgarian Beach
text:
Bulgarian Beach (Balgarsko Kraybrezhie \'b&l-gar-sko krI-'bre-zhi-e\) is a coast in the north part of <a href="Hurd%20Peninsula">Hurd Peninsula</a>, eastern <a href="Livingston%20Island">Livingston Island</a>, extending 2.3 km from Hespérides Point to the southwest to <a href="Perunika%20Glacier">Perunika Glacier</a> to the northeast, and forming the southeast coast of <a href="Emona%20Anchorage">Emona Anchorage</a>.
The beach comprises four predominantly boulder beaches, separated by a shore rock known locally as Greenpeace Rock, which rises to 6m and is located 800 m northeast of <a href="Hesp%C3%A9rides%20Point">Hespérides Point</a>, by <a href="Spanish%20Point%20%28Antarctica%29">Spanish Point</a> and by a minor nameless point lying 400 m to east by northeast of the latter. The last beach is a narrow strip under the cliff of a part of <a href="Perunika%20Glacier">Perunika Glacier</a> terminating on the coast. Bulgarian Beach is surmounted by a chain of five hills comprising <a href="Hesperides%20Hill">Hesperides Hill</a>, <a href="Pesyakov%20Hill">Pesyakov Hill</a>, <a href="Sinemorets%20Hill">Sinemorets Hill</a>, <a href="Spanish%20Knoll">Spanish Knoll</a> and <a href="Belozem%20Hill">Belozem Hill</a>. In summer the area is predominantly snow-free and crossed by four meltwater streams draining the north-western slope of the <a href="Balkan%20Snowfield">Balkan Snowfield</a>, with stream mouths located at the western extremities of each beach. The first beach, locally known as Base Beach, is partly occupied by <a href="Grand%20Lagoon">Grand Lagoon</a> formed by <a href="Rezovski%20Creek">Rezovski Creek</a>. Access by dinghies to Base Beach, used for transfer of people and cargo to the Bulgarian base <a href="St.%20Kliment%20Ohridski%20Base">St. Kliment Ohridski</a>, is sometimes rendered difficult by shallow waters.
The area would have been known and possibly visited in the early nineteenth century by <a href="England">English</a> and American <a href="Seal%20hunter">sealer</a>s frequenting <a href="South%20Bay%2C%20Livingston%20Island">South Bay</a> and particularly the nearby <a href="Johnsons%20Dock">Johnsons Dock</a>.
Location.
The beach is centred at . Bulgarian Beach was mapped in detail by the <a href="Spain">Spanish</a> Servicio Geográfico del Ejército in 1991 following earlier <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a>, <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> and <a href="Chile">Chile</a>an mappings. <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>n mapping of Bulgarian Beach and the <a href="Emona%20Anchorage">Emona Anchorage</a> coast from a topographic survey carried out from 8 December 1995 to 8 February 1996, and mapping of the <a href="St.%20Kliment%20Ohridski%20Base">St. Kliment Ohridski Base</a> vicinity at a larger scale from a topographic survey made from January 31 to February 4, 1996.
